content.title: Nutcracker Syndrome (Left Renal Vein Compression)
content.summary: Compression of the left renal vein between the aorta and superior mesenteric artery (anterior type) or between the aorta and vertebral column (posterior type), causing left renal venous hypertension.

definitions.definition: Symptomatic compression of the left renal vein causing venous hypertension with hematuria, flank pain, and development of collateral veins including varicocele or pelvic congestion.
Anterior (classic): LRV compressed between aorta and SMA. Posterior: retroaortic LRV compressed between aorta and vertebral column.

key_concepts.explanation: Normal angle between aorta and SMA is 38-56 degrees. Reduced angle (<25-30 degrees) predisposes to LRV compression. Thin patients, rapid weight loss, and lordosis can reduce this angle.

Hematuria (micro or macro, often orthostatic), left flank pain (often orthostatic), left-sided varicocele in men, pelvic congestion syndrome in women. Symptoms are often positional and worsen with standing.
Doppler showing LRV velocity ratio >4-5:1 (hilar vs compressed segment). CT/MR showing LRV 'beak sign,' diameter ratio >3:1 (hilar vs narrowed), and collateral veins (gonadal, lumbar).

Conservative: observation in children/adolescents as angle may increase with growth. Interventional: LRV stenting (gaining favor). Surgical: LRV transposition, renal autotransplantation, gonadal vein transposition. Choice depends on patient age and symptom severity.

evidence.citation: Wang et al., LRV Stenting Outcomes, 2017
evidence.finding: Endovascular stenting provides symptom relief in 90% of patients with acceptable complication rates
Conservative management appropriate in children as 75% improve spontaneously with growth and weight gain

clinical_pearls: Consider nutcracker in patients with unexplained left-sided hematuria, especially if orthostatic
In children and adolescents, observation for 2+ years is appropriate as symptoms often resolve with growth
Unilateral left varicocele that doesn't decompress supine should raise suspicion for nutcracker
Stent migration is a significant concern with LRV stenting - careful sizing and positioning are critical
Posterior nutcracker (retroaortic LRV) requires different surgical approach
learning_objectives: Distinguish anterior from posterior nutcracker anatomy
Recognize clinical presentations of nutcracker syndrome
Interpret Doppler and CT criteria for diagnosis
Compare treatment options and appropriate patient selection
Explain the role of conservative management in pediatric patients

cross_domain_references.context: Nutcracker is a vascular cause of hematuria
Renal venous hypertension can predispose to thrombosis
